Do ya?

Well, I recreated that in a bot, that reads from a spreadsheet of your posts, jumbles it, randomizes it, restructures it, and then posts them semi-logically, to Mastodon.

Now, in my use-case for this, I have it reading from Google Sheets Iâ€™ve generated as backups of every single post Iâ€™ve made to Mastodon since the beginning of 2024, because â€¦ I just didnâ€™t know what to do with all of that, until now. I donâ€™t think this is a problem that only exists on Mastodon, though. entry.title: Turning Windows into a Dev Machine

link.title: Turning Windows into a Dev Machine

entry.content:
So, itâ€™s been an interesting week and a half. I started screwing around with Python after spending time casually reading about it, and decided to learn it, hands-on, and I smashed up a slew of interesting things. Then, I started thinking about, despite my love for Linux, and especially Debian, there are some critical things I still donâ€™t have access to while on Linux.

Such as things I use for my creations in Second Life, like Quixel, Marvelous Designer. And how Iâ€™m basically locked to only using Gimp. And, regrettably, there are a few games I want to play that I just canâ€™t. With these things in mind, I decided to mess around and put Windows on my System76 machine. It wasnâ€™t all that painful, because I have all of my important stuff backed up on the cloud, and I donâ€™t mind redownloading games as I decide Iâ€™m interested in playing them.

But â€¦ And this could end up being the reason I decide to just put Linux back onto my PC: Turning Windows into a machine for a developer is a pain in the ass.

From configuring SSH, to realizing I didnâ€™t have OpenSSH, to installing OpenSSH, to configuring PowerShell, to downloading the actual latest version, to screwing with SSH keys, to adding, deleting, adding, deleting, adding, deleting, and adding and deleting about 15 different keys, before I generated a new one, and then manually pasted the key into the authorizations on my Debian server.

Oh, but then thereâ€™s VS Code â€¦ An apparent Microsoft centric developer app, that crashes against a wall as soon as you try to push and sync? Because apparently, or at least in my case, it doesnâ€™t know to use OpenSSH?!

Nevertheless, here I am, with access to all of my games, and every single program I used to use, and also my developer tools setup exactly the same way they were in Pop!_OS.

I do have to say that I really like Pop!_OS, but Iâ€™m not that excited about merging and migrating my entire system to the Rust based COSMIC. I donâ€™t know. I â€¦ kind of like Ubuntu, you know?

All that aside, weâ€™ll see how long this lasts. Despite the shortcomings, Linux is really a revolutionary OS, and Iâ€™ll probably put it all back sometime in the future. Probably when I get tired of the games I wanted to play, and decide to figure out the workarounds for the apps I want to use in Windows (I donâ€™t like using Virtual Machines, I just want to interact with my actual PC).

But, until then, Iâ€™m going to see how far I can stretch Windows into giving me control of the system.

entry.title: Jump on the Bandwagon!
entry.content:
Iâ€™m sure there are those who know that Bandcamp was recently bought out by a company called Songtradr, and this came with much dismay, because Bandcamp has been, and has mostly remained, one of the only music platforms where small artists could actually be discovered, heard, and paid. This is incongruent with current trends of the past decade and a half, of the music industry pushing real hard for streaming. Streaming, which pays fractions of a penny of a penny on a dollar, while the rich consume the profits. This has only been exasperated since AI came into the scene, with people absent of talent and inspiration, generating absolute garbage (and this isnâ€™t just a problem in music, itâ€™s everywhere).

I personally havenâ€™t seen, heard, or noticed any detrimental effects of Bandcamp being bought-out, but itâ€™s good to be prepared. To be prepared in an age where Mozilla is suddenly an ad agency, Microsoft is developing spyware, OpenAI is asking governments for enough electrical power to destroy the entire planet, and Apple is releasing products people donâ€™t want.

Weâ€™re living in a universe that is slowly becoming a perpetual backwards day (not that Microsoft was ever a decent forward-thinking company, or that OpenAI ever had any good intentions with their grift of theft, but I digressâ€¦).

But there are those who read my musings, who know Iâ€™m a freak for the fediverse.

You might guess where this is going.

â€œWait, are you about to tell me that thereâ€™s a motherfugginâ€™ Bandcamp, ON THE FEDIVERSE?â€

Yes, yes I am about to tell you that, Fortnite Gamer.

This morning, while I was slogging away at getting ready for work, I saw a post flash past my Mastodon feed, something like, â€œItâ€™s Bandcamp, but on the fediverse!â€

I thought to myself, â€œHmm, okay. Iâ€™ll bookmark this for 10 hours from now.â€

So, I clicked the link and followed through to Bandwagon.fm, and, my dudes â€¦

I now have a â€œbandcampâ€ on the fediverse, over here.

Save for the ability to actually sell your music (which I assume theyâ€™re working on?), you can upload whole entire albums here, and then people can stumble in and listen to what youâ€™ve made! Thatâ€™s WILD. â€¦ on the FEDIVERSE?!

What I did here with my page, though, is I took the 3 most recent albums I did under Eyeshadow 2600 FM, and re-published them under my new name, PLEXX. Once I finally finish disc eRROR 19â€‹.â€‹92 ~DEâ€‹-â€‹LUX, Iâ€™ll be putting that album there, too.

But this is so cool, and itâ€™s connected to Musicbrainz, another open-source music cataloguing project!

Earlier today, I was having second thoughts about Linux, and sticking to open source and all that. Mostly because, I sort of miss a few programs that Iâ€™m having trouble getting working on Pop!_OS. But this kind of turned me around a bit. Thereâ€™s no reason to go back to the bastardized version of whatever Bill Gates had in mind 30 years ago. This proves to me that regular people will restore the internet to what it should have always been.

The only thing it takes, is patience, and a whole lot less second-guessing myself and my decisions. And also maybe I need to sit in front of my computer screen a little less here and there. My eyes hurt.

Anyway, I canâ€™t wait to see what the heck comes next, holy crap.

entry.title: Life Without a Computer?
entry.content:
Itâ€™s been at least two months since Iâ€™ve done one of Jetpackâ€™s writing prompts. Largely, because, I ditched Wordpress and decided to build something from scratch. It seems, in light of the Wordpress CEOâ€™s recent blunders, it was probably a good idea to abandon Wordpress. But I really only did it because I enjoy writing everything in VS Code, rather than a glitchy editor. Nevertheless, I still have Automatticâ€™s â€œjetpackâ€ app installed on my phone, and it serves me interesting writing prompts every once in a while, and because I donâ€™t enjoy writing about a crisis every single time I fire up the VSC, I think Iâ€™ll snag this one.

So, full-stop, I had access to a computer in about 1992, I believe. I think I spoke about this before, but it was something my Dad was provided by his job, and it wasnâ€™t exactly up-to-date with current versions of Windows. It was more like a mid-80s machine with extremely early versions of DOS, and bulletin boards. The menu was built into a permanent console, like something you write through via Linux (for the zoomies who donâ€™t know what the hell DOS is), and it was â€¦ pretty basic.

I think that thing is still sitting around, somewhere out there.

As time marched forward, we got another PC, and another PC, and then a Gateway 486, and then that was largely what I used, until I was given another â€œhand-me-downâ€-ish PC when I was around 15 or 16. About the time I discovered anime forums, and started e-dating as many girls as I could â€¦ with video chat over aol instant messenger, and â€¦ a whole lot of embarrassing things I probably shouldnâ€™t have been sharing with girls I, ultimately, didnâ€™t really know, at all.

Then, when I graduated, I was gifted another PC, which is when I really started gaming. And then years later I built one myself, and then I upgraded it, and then I bought another PC. And then I ditched that one, and bought one in 2018, and then I ditched that one, too, and bought the powerhouse Linux PC Iâ€™m currently using today (alongside the Windows Dell, and Macbook I have as side machines).

What would life be like, had none of this ever happened?

I guess Iâ€™d probably watch paint dry? Or, am I still allowed to have my iPhone? Cause, if thatâ€™s the case, I guess the only thing thatâ€™d be different is Iâ€™d probably be some kind of prolific mobile gamer, who never got into web development. Maybe Iâ€™d be streaming to Twitch via my phone as I bumble around Genshin Impact. Who knows!

But, letâ€™s say the phone is also a computer.

This question is far too open-ended for the 2020s, donâ€™t you think?

So, no PC, no laptops, no phone, no toasters with touch-screens, and weâ€™ll just assume, in this version of the universe, my job also hasnâ€™t given me a phone to work with.

Alright.

Since television is mainly on streaming now, and basic â€œappointment TVâ€ doesnâ€™t really exist anymore (and by that, I mean, episodic television that isnâ€™t dumped all at once), I guess Iâ€™d probably have a Smart TV, and Iâ€™d probably spend a lot of my time watching shows. Maybe Iâ€™d also read a lot more. I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™d be writing, because â€¦ I guess Iâ€™d have to do that by hand? Like a baby. But, thatâ€™s the thing, a smart TV is also a computer! Weâ€™ll, for the sake of this post, just pretend that it isnâ€™t, though.

I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™d have a richer social life, because I think factors that made it harder for me to connect with people in the 2020s, arenâ€™t really related to having access to a PC, but more that people in-general are, or have, isolated themselves in their own little bubbles of media that they themselves dictate. Which, in-turn, makes casual conversation impossible.

But â€¦ without access to all of the worldâ€™s knowledge and information, I guess Iâ€™d probably be a lot more uninformed. Iâ€™d probably be much more susceptible to just believing anything anyone tells me. Iâ€™d probably question things less. I wouldnâ€™t have random college credits sitting on my name, and I guess I wouldnâ€™t have a resume, either?

Jesus.

Uh, I think weâ€™ll skip this universe.

I think itâ€™s pretty important to have access to technology, and the internet. Because, just sitting here thinking about what life would be like without all this stuff, sounds â€¦ horrifying. And, maybe thatâ€™s nerdy. But damn, dude, no. No I donâ€™t think Iâ€™d want to live a life of watching TV and sleeping.

entry.title: You Wake Up, And Itâ€™s 2012 Again

link.title: You Wake Up, And Itâ€™s 2012 Again

entry.content:
Iâ€™ve written a lot about how much I miss the 90s, and sometimes pine for an age in the 80s, and, obviously, Iâ€™m not talking â€¦ politically. But more, a time when things were less chaotic, and we were all kinda just vibing with whatever was happening. Drinking our Ecto-Coolers, slipping on Velcro sneakers, uh, watching Rockoâ€™s Modern Life.

But sometimes I also wish it was still 2012. Still in the midst of the Mass Effect trilogy, the greatest game series ever created. Still logging onto a mostly normal Facebook to get my daily clicks in Mafia Wars and Farmville.

A time when Sims 3 was the latest and greatest of the franchise, and all I was doing in the game was walking my sim around collecting diamonds and rocks, and trying to figure out what kind of bathroom she should have. When I was still mystified by new experiences, and finding wonder in exploring new narratives. Back when the iPhone still had what I think were the best icon graphics, a headphone jack, and iPods! Yeah, I had an iPod Touch! â€¦that I played digital poker with.

When Iâ€™d jump on Google cam-chats with friends, lay in bed, and just talk all night long, and when Youtube was just a place where people uploaded random weird stuff that wasnâ€™t designed to pull you in and keep you there for ad-rolls and sponsored segments.

â€¦ when cigarettes only cost like, four dollars a pack.

A year wherein Iâ€™d get out of work and still have the energy to do things that I enjoy.

I miss 2012.

Thereâ€™s no use living in the past, but there were a lot of great things about technology in the 90s, and 2000s, and even 2010. And then suddenly it all started going downhill. Things advanced, but for no reason. Oh boy, bigger cameras, larger screens, thinner bezels, s â€¦ streaming? I donâ€™t own my music and movies anymore? All the casual games I liked using to pass time are on my phone? Sweet! â€¦ oh, almost all of them are copies of each other and filled with so much money-grubbing they could only really be classified as a game for the first 5 minutes that you interact with it?

Instagram is about posting engagement-bait and getting popular with short-form content until you can â€¦ get sponsored with product placement?

Twitter got murdered by Elon Musk and now itâ€™s just nazis and ai-gen spam?

What the heck?

I miss 2012.

Itâ€™s not all bad. We got Mastodon, we got a federated network of users taking ownership of their content, and the indie web (a revival of the 90s internet). There are still good games out there, and a whole lot of indie developers who make some real gems. But, man, do you really have to sift through mountains and oceans of garbage to find content and entertainment actually worth consuming.

Or, maybe Iâ€™m just getting older, and everything is just fine the way it is.

Who knows.
